articles.description: Are you more likely to die on your birthday? Yes.
articles.title: Are you more likely to die on your birthday?

articles.author: Elizabeth Landau
articles.description:
Slight changes in the number, shape, efficiency and interconnectedness of organelles in the cells of flight muscles provide extra energy for birds’ continent-spanning feats.            
The post ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: ‘Turbocharged’ Mitochondria Power Birds’ Epic Migratory Journeys

articles.author: Joseph Howlett
articles.description:
Turbulence is a notoriously difficult phenomenon to study. Mathematicians are now starting to untangle it at its smallest scales.            
The post New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: New ‘Superdiffusion’ Proof Probes the Mysterious Math of Turbulence

articles.author: Janna Levin and Steven Strogatz
articles.description:
Geometry may have its origins thousands of years ago in ancient land surveying, but it has also had a surprising impact on modern physics. In the latest episode of The Joy of Why, Yang-Hui He explores geometry’s evolution and its future potential through AI.            
The post How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics? first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How Did Geometry Create Modern Physics?

articles.author: Zack Savitsky
articles.description:
From living matter to molecules to elementary particles, the world is made of “chiral” objects that differ from their reflected forms.            
The post How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: How the Universe Differs From Its Mirror Image

articles.author: Samir Patel
articles.description:
Exploring the distant universe, the insides of cells, the abstractions of math, the complexity of information itself and much more, The Quanta Podcast will be a tour of the frontier between the known and the unknown.             
The post Introducing The Quanta Podcast first appeared on Quanta Magazine
articles.title: Introducing The Quanta Podcast

articles.description: For many years, the Drug Policy Alliance (DPA) maintained a large library of books on drug use and policy at its New York City headquarters. As researchers shifted to working […]
articles.title: New Digital Collection Preserves Key Books on Drug Use and Policy

articles.description: America’s roads are more dangerous than those of almost every country in the developed world. We know how to change that.
articles.title: Traffic Fatalities Are a Choice

articles.description: Building a high-speed rail between Los Angeles and San Francisco was never going to be easy — but the critics who write it off are missing the real source of the project’s struggles.
articles.title: Reports of the Death of  California High-Speed Rail Have Been Greatly Exaggerated

articles.description: Everyone likes the idea of evidence-based policy, but it’s hard to realize it when our most reputable social science journals are still publishing poor quality research.
articles.title: Can We Trust Social Science Yet?

articles.description: A conversation about the factors that might slow down the pace of AI development, what could happen next, and whether we’ll be able to see it coming.
articles.title: Does AI Progress Have a Speed Limit?

articles.description: Kelsey Piper and Jasmine Sun talk about microschools, whether localism is the enemy of Abundance, and why Chinese bureaucrats are like Growth PMs.
articles.title: Does Abundance Start at Home?

articles.description: "I can't believe I missed it because it's so obvious. No excuses," the writer said. "I'm completely embarrassed."
articles.title: Chicago Sun-Times Prints AI-Generated Summer Reading List With Books That Don't Exist

articles.description: 404 Media found that people were using Civitai to create nonconsensual AI porn videos of anyone for a small price.

articles.description: According to its newest transparency report, Telegram complied with more than 5,000 requests from authorities in the first three months of 2025.

articles.description: 23andMe sold the genetic data of 15 million people for $256 million to a pharmaceutical company called Regeneron.

articles.description: The tool scans for users writing certain keywords on Reddit and assigns those users a so-called “radical score,” before deploying an AI-powered bot to automatically engage with the users to de-radicalize them.
articles.title: Student Makes Tool That Identifies ‘Radicals’ on Reddit, Deploys AI Bots to Engage With Them

articles.description: This week, we have stories about wild horses, wild chimps, and wild cosmic deaths.

articles.title: CBP Seizes Shipment of T-Shirts Featuring Swarm of Bees Attacking a Cop

articles.title: ‘Doom: The Dark Ages’ DRM Is Locking Out Linux Users Who Bought the Game

articles.author: Samantha Cole
articles.description: "Thinking about your ex 24/7? There's nothing wrong with you. Chat with their AI version—and finally let it go," an ad for Closure says. I tested a bunch of the chatbot startups' personas.
articles.title: This Chatbot Promises to Help You Get Over That Ex Who Ghosted You

articles.description: Large language models are reflections of the people who program them.

articles.description: Thousands of pages of documents show school districts around the country did not understand how much ChatGPT would change their classrooms, and pro-AI consultants filled in some of the gaps.
articles.title: American Schools Were Deeply Unprepared for ChatGPT, Public Records Show

articles.description: Flock, which has license plate readers (LPRs) all around the country, wants police to be able to “jump from LPR to person,” according to leaked audio obtained by 404 Media.
articles.title: License Plate Reader Company Flock Is Building a Massive People Lookup Tool, Leak Shows

articles.description: We have the technology to detect airborne pathogens in real time. Now we must use it.

articles.author: Asimov Press
articles.description: The modern centrifuge was first designed for milkfat separation in the dairy industry. Today, it is ubiquitous in research laboratories. To whom do we owe its astonishing versatility?
articles.title: Making the Centrifuge

articles.description: How a chance discovery in bioluminescent jellyfish led to one of the most transformative tools in modern biology: green fluorescent protein.
articles.title: A Brief History of GFP

articles.author: Hiya Jain
articles.description: In 2017, there were just over 600 clinical trials initiated in China. By 2023, that number was nearly 2,000. How can American companies kick off a similar boom?
articles.title: China’s Clinical Trial Boom

articles.description: With a litany of gene therapies and longevity medicine staving off biological death, those paid to write about it must reimagine their craft.
